Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother: “Don’t forget, my graduation’s at 2 PM! Can’t wait to see you there!” I smiled, feeling proud and excited for him. As his sister, I knew how much this day meant to him—and to our whole family. We’d always promised to show up for each other’s big moments, and I wanted to be there, cheering him on as he walked across the stage.

But as I glanced at my work calendar, my heart sank. Our weekly team meeting was scheduled for the exact same time. My manager had emphasized the importance of everyone’s presence, even though the meeting would be recorded for those who couldn’t attend. I could already imagine the subtle disappointment in my colleagues’ faces if I skipped out, especially since we were supposed to discuss a project I’d been leading.

I sat at my desk, torn between the expectation to support my brother and the responsibility to my team. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I felt the familiar ache of wanting to be in two places at once, knowing I could only choose one.
